column1: #Text=How to tune Nextcloud on-premise cloud server for better performance - TechRepublic
#Text=How to tune Nextcloud on-premise cloud server for better performance
#Text=Jack Wallen offers tips on configuring Nextcloud for performance that should better meet your demands.
#Text=Nextcloud is, hands down, the best on-premise cloud server platform on the market.
#Text=Not only is it easy to deploy, it's also reliable and expandable.
#Text=However, out of the box, you might find the platform's performance doesn't quite meet your expectations.
#Text=Fear not, there are ways you can eke out a bit more performance from the platform.
#Text=Let me offer you up a few tips.
#Text=SEE: Managing the multicloud (ZDNet/TechRepublic special feature) | Download the free PDF version (TechRepublic) \tWhat you'll need
#Text=In order to tune Nextcloud, you'll need a running instance of the platform.
#Text=These tips should work with any iteration of Nextcloud from 16 on.
#Text=You'll also need a user with sudo privileges.
#Text=5 programming languages cloud engineers should learn
#Text=AWS: 9 pro tips and best practices (free PDF)
#Text=The first tip is to enable caching on your Nextcloud server.
#Text=I've already covered this in my piece "How to enable caching on Nextcloud 16."
#Text=With caching enabled, you increase performance by storing frequently requested objects in memory for faster retrieval.
#Text=This should be one of the first configurations you take care of, in order to squeeze out as much performance as possible.
#Text=Do take care, as enabling caching is a bit tricky.
#Text=How to enable HTTP2 HTTP2 is the latest HTTP protocol and allows web browsers to send multiple, simultaneous requests to a server.
#Text=HTTP2 is well supported by Apache, so it's not at all challenging to enable.
#Text=This is another issue I've tackled before, so you can easily enable HTTP2 on Apache by following the tutorial, "How to enable HTTP/2 Protocol on Ubuntu 16.04."

#Text=How to optimize PHP-FPM The default PHP-FPM installation on your server might be the cause of excessive load times for Nextcloud--each request for an element is handled by a separate PHP-FPM process.
#Text=By allowing numerous PHP-FPM processes to run, you should gain a considerable increase in performance.
#Text=Open the necessary configuration file for editing with the command: sudo nano /etc/php/7.X/fpm/pool.d/www.conf
#Text=Where X is your current installed version of PHP.
#Text=In that file, you'll need to look for the following lines: pm = dynamic
#Text=The above configuration changes will work for a server that has 4 GB of RAM and a 1 GB  MySQL cache.
#Text=Edit the above options and save and close the file.
#Text=Restart apache with the command: sudo systemctl restart apache2
#Text=Once you've taken care of the above optimizations, you should find that Nextcloud performs considerably better.
#Text=As my last bit of advice, you might want to run these on a non-production environment, to ensure you nail the configurations.
#Text=Once you see the increase in performance, you can then make the changes on your production environment.
#Text=Subscribe to TechRepublic's How To Make Tech Work on YouTube for all the latest tech advice for business pros from Jack Wallen.
